column5: Please list the publisher and author of your grammar
column6: Would you recommend the grammar that you worked with to future students of LIN 360 (on the merits of its clarity, organization, etc.)?
column7: 1. Which of the following morphological types does your language fall into *primarily*?
column8: 2. What sorts of morphological word-formation strategies does your language use?
column9: 3. Which of these best describes the frequency of different types of AFFIXATION in your language?
column10: 4. Which of these best describes the frequency of NON-affixational word-formation strategies in your language?
column11: 5. What sorts of functional morphology does your language have (whether affixal, through a morphological process, or free i.e. as a function word)?
column12: 6. What is(/are) the basic word order(s) of your language?
column13: 7. How does your language pattern with respect to headedness?

column5: Author: Stacy Fang-Ching Teng; Publisher: Canberra, A.C.T. : Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University
column6: Yes, my grammar was fine to work with (even if not perfect)
column7: Agglutinating (= synthetic and has few/no "fused" morphemes, potentially just fused morphemes of the most common type, which is person+number)
column9: Roughly even mix of prefixing and suffixing
column10: Most word-formation involves affixation (rather than non-affixal word-formation strategies)
column11: Nominalizers;Verbalizers;Other verbal derivational morphology (e.g., causative, applicative, passive, reflexive)

column6: Maybe, but only because he was very inconsistent with IPA and glossing, as it seemed he just combined different texts without putting them into the same format. This made the work very confusing. Also, there were at least two sections that were in the table of contents that just didn't exist, which made the work difficult as well. All in all, it was doable, it was just more difficult than it needed to be.
